0.2.title: AI Usage Regulation
0.2.objective: Learn the rules of CNJ Resolution 615/2025 (Brazilian National Council of Justice) for AI use in the Judiciary.
0.2.content:
‚öñÔ∏è CNJ Resolution 615/2025

Establishes the Artificial Intelligence Usage Policy in the Brazilian Judiciary.

Fundamental Principles

PrincipleWhat it meansStatus
Prior trainingMandatory training on limitations, risks, and ethical use ‚Äî provided by courtsMANDATORY
Auxiliary natureUse only as support ‚Äî autonomous use for judicial decisions is prohibitedMANDATORY
ResponsibilityJudge remains fully responsible ‚Äî verification and review requiredMANDATORY
Data protectionUse of data for training without express authorization is prohibitedMANDATORY
Confidential dataPrior anonymization required ‚Äî do not input confidential documents without treatmentMANDATORY
Usage loggingAutomatic logging in Court system ‚Äî mention in decision is optionalRECOMMENDED

What IS ALLOWED (Low Risk)

CategoryPermitted Uses
TRANSFORMATIONWriting: Text correction and improvement, idea organization, summary and report drafting, document drafts
Analysis: Case analysis (FIRAC+), fact extraction, descriptive evidence analysis
RESEARCHSimple: Precedent and information research
Deep: Doctrine, evidence-based reasoning, precedents, complex case analysis
CREATIONBrainstorming: Idea and argument generation, objections, counterfactual thinking
Suggestions: Questions and queries
Artifacts: Websites, dashboards, slides, mind maps

What is NOT ALLOWED (High Risk and Excessive Risk)

CategoryProhibited Uses
JUDGMENTDecision-making: Systems without human supervision, absolute automation
Conclusive judgments: Law application, rights plausibility, crime classification
Evidence evaluation: Validity, probative force, standards
IMPACT ON RIGHTSPeople assessment: Predicting crimes/recidivism, profiling by social behavior, emotion identification
Quantification: Sentence dosimetry, moral damages
PRIVACYConfidential proceedings: Without prior anonymization
Training: Models that use user data
Credibility: Testimony classification (lie detection)

0.3.title: Privacy Configuration
0.3.objective: Configure your LLM for professional use by disabling data usage for training.
0.3.content:
Your Conversations Are Private

Conversations between you and the AI model are private. They don't become public, aren't shared with other users, and don't appear in internet searches.

Major LLM providers treat your conversations as confidential data:

ModelWhat it guaranteesPrivacy Policy
ClaudeConversations stored securely, not shared publiclyAnthropic Privacy Policy
ChatGPTUser data protected, option to disable historyOpenAI Privacy Policy
GeminiConversations processed according to Google policiesGemini Apps Privacy
üîê Private ‚â† Can Be Used for Training

Privacy: Your conversations are not public ‚Äî third parties don't have access.

Training: Different issue ‚Äî the provider may use your data to improve the model, unless you disable this option.

For Judiciary use, you need to ensure both: privacy AND training opt-out.

Why Configure Opt-out?

Resolution 615/2025 determines that Judiciary data cannot be used for training AI models. You need to ensure training opt-out.

Configuration in Claude

In Claude, the option is called "Help improve Claude" and must be DISABLED.

Claude privacy screen ‚Äî training toggle DISABLED

üìù History vs Training

History: Your conversations are saved for you to access later ‚Äî this is useful and allowed.

Training: Your data is used to improve the model ‚Äî this is prohibited in the Judiciary.

NO. You still need to anonymize confidential data. Disabling training is one layer, anonymization is another.

0.4.title: Interface and Navigation
0.4.objective: Learn the essential elements of an LLM interface ‚Äî valid for any model.
0.4.content:
‚ö° Interfaces Change Constantly

LLM interfaces (Claude, ChatGPT, Gemini) are updated frequently. Models also evolve ‚Äî new versions are released every few months.

Don't worry: the essential elements remain the same across all platforms. If you understand these elements, you can use any LLM.

Essential Elements (Common to All LLMs)

Regardless of the model or version, every LLM interface has these basic elements:

ElementWhat it isFunction
Chat AreaThe central space on the screenWhere the conversation happens: you type (input) and the model responds (output). It's the heart of the interface.
Text FieldInput box at the bottomWhere you type your questions and instructions. Supports long texts.
Attachment ButtonUsually a [+] or paperclip iconAllows you to send files (PDFs, images, documents) for the model to analyze.
New ConversationButton to start a new chatCreates a clean conversation, with no memory of the previous conversation.
SettingsSettings menu (usually ‚öôÔ∏è icon)Privacy, preferences, plan, customization.
üß† Fundamental Concept: Each Conversation is an Isolated Context

When you click "New Conversation", you are starting a completely new session.

The model does not know what was discussed in previous conversations. It's as if you were talking to a different person who did not participate in past conversations.

Practical implication: If you need the model to remember something, you must include that information in the current conversation (or use Projects with fixed instructions).

Claude Interface Overview

Claude interface: essential elements present in all LLM platforms

0.5.title: Custom Settings
0.5.objective: Understand the personalization and memory features of LLMs ‚Äî and why they are not recommended for legal use.
0.5.content:
What is Personalization?

Personalization allows you to define custom instructions that apply to all your conversations. It's a fixed text that the model always considers before responding.

Example: "Always respond in formal English" or "I am a tax lawyer, adapt responses to this context".

Personalization settings in Claude ‚Äî instructions that apply to all conversations

What is Memory?

Memory allows the model to remember specific details from previous conversations. The model automatically extracts "memories" and uses them to contextualize future conversations.

Example: If you mention that you are a federal judge in one conversation, the model may remember this in future conversations.

Memory settings in Claude ‚Äî memories extracted from previous conversations

‚ö†Ô∏è Not Recommended for Legal Use

Global personalization and memory are useful only for those who use LLMs for very specific purposes and homogeneous tasks.

For the legal reality ‚Äî with varied demands and diverse contexts ‚Äî there is no advantage in using these features globally.

Problems with Global Use

ProblemWhat happens
Context pollutionIrrelevant information takes up space in the context window, reducing the model's capacity
Memory contaminationDetails from one case "leak" into analyses of completely different cases
DistractionThe model considers information that is not relevant to the current task
Style interferenceA globally defined style interferes when you need a different approach (neutral report vs argumentative reasoning)

The Alternative: Per-Project Customization

Instead of configuring globally, use the project features of each platform:

PlatformFeatureWhat it does
ClaudeProjectsGroups conversations with isolated specific instructions
ChatGPTCustom GPTsCreates "versions" of ChatGPT with specific behavior
GeminiGemsPersonalized assistants for specific tasks

Advantage: Each project/GPT/Gem has its own isolated context, without contaminating others.

It seems efficient, but when you want to explore the plaintiff's arguments or simulate a lawyer's perspective, the model will insist on the judge's posture. Solution: Use Projects with specific instructions for each context.

0.6.title: Agentic Features
0.6.objective: Understand that current AI assistants have tools that activate automatically ‚Äî and that the response does not always come directly from the model.
0.6.content:
Before and Now

Before
Question
‚Üì
Model responds
‚Üì
Response
Resources: chat + attachment
Source: internal knowledge (training)
Now
Instruction
‚Üì
Model decides
‚Üì
Tools
Search Thinking Analysis Artifacts Code
‚Üì
Response
Resources: chat + attachment + tools
Source: model + external tools

The fundamental difference: the model now decides whether it needs to activate external tools. This changes the source of the response.

What are Agentic Features?

These are external tools that the model can activate to complement its response:

ToolWhat it doesExample use
Web searchSearches for information in real timeRecent case law, news, updated regulations
Extended thinkingDeeper reasoning before respondingComplex problems, analyses requiring reflection
Data analysisProcesses spreadsheets and extracts patternsTables with lots of data, statistical calculations
ArtifactsCreates structured documentsTables, code, formatted documents
Code executionRuns code for precise calculationsComplex mathematical operations

How Are Tools Activated?

There are three ways:

MethodDescriptionExample
By requestYou explicitly ask"Search the web for..." / "Use extended thinking"
By authorizationYou enable the tool and the model decides when to use itEnable web search in settings
By own initiativeThe model decides on its own that it needs the toolCreate artifact when you ask for a table

This is the concept of agency: the model has the ability to decide and execute actions beyond simply responding.

‚ö†Ô∏è The Response Does Not Always Come from the Model

When a tool is activated, part of the response comes from the tool, not from the model's internal knowledge.

Example: If the model searches the web, the information came from the internet ‚Äî with all the advantages (up-to-date) and risks (unverified sources) that this implies.

üí° Claude's Advantage: Transparency

Claude always informs when it is using a tool. You see messages like "Searching the web...", "Creating artifact...", "Analyzing...".

Other models (ChatGPT, Gemini) also use tools, but don't always inform. With Claude, you know the source of the information.

1.1.title: LLMs as Creative Machines
1.1.objective: Understand that LLMs do not reproduce texts from the past ‚Äî they transform the present and create the future.
1.1.content:
The Common (and Wrong) Assumption

Many people think that using LLMs is:

  • Cheating ‚Äî "it's copying from somewhere"
  • Unethical ‚Äî "it's stealing other people's work"
  • Something for lazy minds ‚Äî "they don't want to think for themselves"

This assumption comes from a misunderstanding of how LLMs work.

Google Mode vs LLM Mode

Google ModeLLM Mode
Reproduces the pastTransforms the present
Written, published, and indexed filesThere are no files inside the LLM
The original file is faithfully reproducedEach response is unique and created in the moment
Search ‚Üí Find ‚Üí ReproduceProcess ‚Üí Transform ‚Üí Create
There are no PDFs inside the LLM

The LLM does not query a "text database". There are no PDFs, DOCs, or files inside it.

What exists are parameters ‚Äî billions of numbers (weights) that encode statistical language patterns.

Each Response is Unique

When you ask the LLM a question:

  • It does not search for a ready-made answer in some database
  • It generates a new response, token by token
  • The response is a mosaic of statistical possibilities
  • It rarely "regurgitates" ‚Äî reproduces verbatim something it saw during training
The Artist Metaphor

An artist who studied thousands of paintings is not "copying" when painting something new. They learned techniques and apply them in an original way.

The LLM does something similar: it learned language patterns and recombines them in new ways.

What LLMs Really Are

ConceptExplanation
Large Language ModelLarge-scale language models
TrainingTrained on trillions of texts to predict the next word
InsideThere are no texts ‚Äî there are numbers (parameters)
OperationMachines of transformation and creation, not reproduction

Recombination

Recombination of patterns can result in:

  • Something similar to what already exists (common patterns)
  • Something completely unusual (new combinations)

This is why the LLM can be creative: it is not limited to reproducing ‚Äî it recombines in ways that may never have existed before.

1.1.warning:
"The LLM is copying texts from the internet."
That's not how it works. The LLM was trained on texts, but stored statistical patterns, not the texts themselves. It generates new responses using those patterns.

1.2.title: Language Machines
1.2.objective: Understand the Transformer architecture and the attention mechanism that revolutionized language processing.
1.2.content:
What is a Transformer?

A Transformer is the neural network architecture behind all modern LLMs (Claude, ChatGPT, Gemini). It was introduced in 2017 in Google's paper "Attention is All You Need".

Think of the LLM as a statistical language compressor:

AnalogyWhat it does
JPEG for imagesCompresses millions of pixels into visual patterns
LLM for languageCompresses billions of texts into probabilistic patterns

It's lossy compression: it preserves the essence, not exact reproduction. That's why LLMs capture general patterns but may err on specific details.

Self-Attention: The Cocktail Party Metaphor

The central mechanism of the Transformer is self-attention. Imagine a party:

The Word Party

You're at a cocktail party where everyone is talking at once. You hear everyone, but your brain focuses on the relevant conversations for what you want to understand.

In the Transformer, each word "looks" at all others and decides which ones are important to understand the meaning in that context.

Practical example:

"The judge analyzed the case and determined that the manufacturing process was irregular."

The word "process" and "case" have context-dependent meanings. The attention mechanism allows the model to understand:

  • "case" ‚Üí legal context (near "judge", "analyzed")
  • "process" ‚Üí industrial context (near "manufacturing")

Tokens: The Processing Units

LLMs don't process words ‚Äî they process tokens (subwords).

WordPossible Tokenization
transformation["trans", "form", "ation"]
unconstitutionality["un", "constitu", "tional", "ity"]
LLM["LL", "M"] or ["LLM"]

Why tokens? They allow a finite vocabulary (~50,000-100,000) to represent infinite words, including neologisms and technical terms.

Rule of thumb: In English, 1 token ‚âà 0.75 words (or ~4 characters).

Embeddings: Words as Coordinates

Each token is converted into a vector ‚Äî a list of numbers that represents its meaning in a high-dimensional mathematical space.

The Semantic Map

Imagine a map where similar words are geometrically close:

‚Ä¢ "king" and "queen" are close
‚Ä¢ "dog" and "cat" are close
‚Ä¢ "king" and "dog" are distant

The famous math: "king" - "man" + "woman" ‚âà "queen"

This allows the model to capture semantic relationships between concepts ‚Äî the basis for "understanding" language.

Visual Summary

INPUT TEXT ‚Üì [Tokenization] ‚Üí Splits into tokens ‚Üì [Embedding] ‚Üí Converts to numerical vectors ‚Üì [Self-Attention] ‚Üí Each token "looks" at others ‚Üì [Transformer Layers] ‚Üí Processes patterns (√ó12 to √ó96 layers) ‚Üì [Output] ‚Üí Probabilities for next token

1.3.title: The Guessing Game
1.3.objective: Understand that LLMs generate text by predicting the next token ‚Äî like a sophisticated autocomplete.
1.3.content:
Try the Prediction Game

Before we explain the theory, try it yourself to see how LLMs generate text. Choose words to continue the story and see the probabilities in action:

Interactive content unavailable.

Open the Prediction Game in a new tab

Interactive game: choose words and see how next-token prediction works

The World's Most Sophisticated Autocomplete

LLMs work like your phone's autocomplete ‚Äî but with billions of parameters and trained on trillions of texts.

The process is simple:

Input: "The judge ordered the" ‚Üì Model calculates probabilities for ALL possible tokens: ‚Ä¢ "arrest" ‚Üí 15% ‚Ä¢ "release" ‚Üí 12% ‚Ä¢ "summons" ‚Üí 8% ‚Ä¢ "subpoena" ‚Üí 7% ‚Ä¢ ... (50,000+ options) ‚Üì Chooses one token (e.g., "arrest") ‚Üì Repeats the process: "The judge ordered the arrest" ‚Üì Next token: "of" (most likely given the context)

This is called autoregressive generation: each token is generated conditioned on all previous ones.

Temperature: The "Creativity" Control

The temperature parameter controls how the model chooses among possible tokens:

TemperatureBehaviorWhen to use
0.0 (cold)Always chooses the most likely (deterministic)Facts, data, precision
0.5-0.7Balanced: likely but with variationWriting, analyses
1.0+ (hot)More random, chooses less likely tokensBrainstorming, creativity
Try Temperature in Action!

Move the slider to see how different temperature values affect the model's "creativity":

Interactive content unavailable.

Open Temperature demonstration in a new tab

The Wine Metaphor

Temperature 0 = Sober ‚Äî responds predictably and safely

Temperature 1.5 = Tipsy ‚Äî creative responses, but may "ramble"

The Paradox: Determinism vs Creativity

A counterintuitive fact:

LLMs are Deterministic!

Given the same input and the same seed (random seed), the model produces exactly the same response.

The "creativity" we observe comes from probabilistic sampling ‚Äî the model draws from the options, weighted by probabilities.

Practical implication: If you need consistent and reproducible responses, use low temperature. If you need variation and different ideas, use higher temperature.

Other Sampling Strategies

StrategyWhat it doesAnalogy
GreedyAlways chooses the most likely tokenAlways ordering the most popular dish
Top-kConsiders only the k most likely tokensChoosing among the 5 most popular dishes
Top-p (nucleus)Considers tokens that sum to p% probabilityChoosing among dishes that represent 90% of orders

In practice, most interfaces already configure these parameters. Claude uses balanced values by default.

Why Does This Matter?

Understanding token prediction explains several behaviors:

  • Why does the model "make things up"? It completes what is statistically likely, even without knowing if it's true
  • Why do responses vary? Probabilistic sampling produces different results
  • Why is it sometimes repetitive? Low temperature = always chooses the most likely
  • Why can it be incoherent? Each token is chosen locally, without a "global plan"

1.3.tip: For tasks that require consistency (reports, analyses), prefer instructions that ask for objective responses. For brainstorming, explicitly ask for variations and alternatives.
1.3.warning:
"The model thought and decided to write this."
There is no 'thought' in the human sense. The model calculates probabilities and samples ‚Äî it's a statistical process, not deliberative. Each token is chosen without a 'plan' for the complete text.

1.4.title: Stochastic Machines
1.4.objective: Recognize that LLMs provide different responses with each interaction, because their processing is probabilistic and stochastic.
1.4.content:
What is Stochastic?

In the previous lesson, you learned that LLMs work as "guessing machines" ‚Äî predicting the next token based on probabilities. Now let's explore a fundamental consequence of this: LLMs are stochastic machines.

Stochastic means "based on probability and randomness". Unlike a calculator that always gives the same result for 2+2, an LLM can give different answers to the same question.

// Calculator (deterministic) 2 + 2 = 4 (always) 2 + 2 = 4 (always) 2 + 2 = 4 (always) // LLM (stochastic) "Tell me a fruit" ‚Üí "Apple" "Tell me a fruit" ‚Üí "Banana" "Tell me a fruit" ‚Üí "Orange"

Why Do Responses Vary?

Remember: the model calculates a probability distribution for each token. For the question "Tell me a fruit", the distribution might be:

TokenProbability
Apple35%
Banana25%
Orange20%
Strawberry10%
Others10%

The model samples from this distribution ‚Äî like spinning a biased roulette wheel. "Apple" has the highest chance of coming up, but it's not guaranteed. Each run is a new spin of the wheel.

Hidden Patterns in Training Data

Although responses vary, they follow statistical patterns learned during training. Some curious examples:

QuestionMost frequent responseWhy?
"Tell me a fruit"AppleMost cited fruit in texts
"Tell me a tool"HammerCulturally iconic tool
"Think of a number from 1 to 100"27 or 37"Random" numbers preferred by humans

LLMs absorb cultural and statistical biases from training data. When humans write "choose a random number", they tend to choose numbers like 27 or 37. The model learned this pattern.

Regression to the Mode

In statistics, there's the concept of regression to the mean: in repeated measurements, extreme values tend to approach the mean. LLMs exhibit a similar but different phenomenon: regression to the mode.

The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a dataset. In LLMs, this means the model tends to gravitate toward the most common responses in the training data.

// Regression to the Mean (traditional statistics) Extreme values ‚Üí tend toward the MEAN (central value) // Regression to the Mode (LLMs) Possible responses ‚Üí tend toward the MODE (most frequent)

Why does this happen? The model was trained to predict the most likely next token. "Most likely" means "most frequent in training data". Therefore, without specific instructions, the model naturally gravitates toward:

Task TypeThe Mode (most common response)
Writing an introductionGeneric formulas ("In today's world...", "It is known that...")
Analyzing a contractObvious points that any analysis would mention
Suggesting argumentsMost common arguments in case law
Summarizing a textStandard academic summary structure

Crucial implication: Without specific instructions, you will receive the "average" response ‚Äî the one that appears most frequently in similar texts. To get differentiated responses, you need to move the model away from the mode with precise instructions, specific examples, or by explicitly asking for unconventional approaches.

Frequency Bias

Regression to the mode is a manifestation of a broader phenomenon: frequency bias. The model reproduces patterns in proportion to how often they appear in training data.

// In training data: "Apple" appears 10,000 times as an example of fruit "Jabuticaba" appears 500 times as an example of fruit // In model response: "Apple" has ~20x more chance of being generated than "Jabuticaba"

Practical consequences of frequency bias:

AreaWhat is more frequent in the dataWhat the model tends to generate
JurisdictionAmerican law texts (in English)Common law concepts even when asked about civil law
Case LawMost cited higher courtsSupreme Court, even when regional courts would be more relevant
ArgumentsMajority and consolidated theses"Safe" arguments instead of innovative theses
StyleTraditional formal legal languageElaborate text even when clarity is requested
Legal DoctrineMost cited authors (classics)References to famous scholars, not necessarily the most appropriate

Why does this matter in Law? Frequency bias can make the model:

  • Favor majority interpretations over minority ones (even when the minority view is more appropriate for the case)
  • Reproduce historical biases present in case law
  • Suggest "standard" solutions when the case requires creativity
  • Ignore local specificities in favor of more universal patterns

Antidote: Be specific. Instead of "analyze this contract", say "analyze this commercial lease agreement from the tenant's perspective, identifying potentially abusive clauses according to consumer protection law and regional court jurisprudence".

Practical Implications

SituationConsequenceWhat to do
Generate creative textsEach generation is uniqueGenerate several versions and choose
Document analysisMay highlight different aspectsRun multiple times, compare
Objective tasksResponses may vary slightlyUse more specific instructions
ReproducibilityDifficult to get exact same responseAccept variation or use fixed seed

1.5.title: The Reversal Curse
1.5.objective: Recognize that LLMs learn based on word frequency in the training data, performing well in one direction but struggling in reverse.
1.5.content:
What is the Reversal Curse?

The Reversal Curse is a phenomenon documented in a 2023 study that demonstrates a fundamental limitation of LLMs: they learn associations in a specific direction, not bidirectionally like humans.

If an LLM learned that "A is related to B" in the training data, it doesn't necessarily deduce that "B is related to A".

// Human (bidirectional relationship) "Tom Cruise was married to Nicole Kidman" ‚Üî automatically knows that "Nicole Kidman was married to Tom Cruise" // LLM (unidirectional relationship) "Tom Cruise ‚Üí Nicole Kidman" ‚úì (frequent direction in data) "Nicole Kidman ‚Üí Tom Cruise" ‚úó (rare direction, may fail)

Why Does This Happen?

Remember: LLMs are token prediction machines trained on text. They learn patterns in the order they appear in the data.

In training dataWhat the model learns
"Tom Cruise, famous actor, was married to Nicole Kidman..."Tom Cruise ‚Üí Nicole Kidman (strong)
Rare mentions of "Nicole Kidman's ex-husband" as the main subjectNicole Kidman ‚Üí ? (weak)

The direction "famous person ‚Üí spouse" appears thousands of times. The reverse direction "spouse ‚Üí famous person" almost never appears as a pattern in texts.

1.5.warning:

Wrong. This is the reversal curse. LLMs don't make automatic logical inferences ‚Äî they reproduce statistical patterns. If the reversal isn't in the training data, the model doesn't 'deduce' it on its own.

1.6.title: The Context Window
1.6.objective: Master the concept of context window - your superpower and your kryptonite when using LLMs.
1.6.content:
What is a Context Window?

The Context Window is the amount of text that the machine can "pay attention to" at the same time. The model only sees a limited window - and forgets what falls too far behind.

ModelStandard WindowExtended Window (beta)
GPT-4o (2024)128K tokens-
Claude 3.5 Sonnet200K tokens-
Claude Opus 4200K tokens-
Gemini 2.01M tokens2M tokens

In practice, 200K tokens is roughly equivalent to 500 pages of text or an entire book. But beware: this doesn't mean you can attach 500 pages. The context window must also contain the system prompt and the model's responses. Therefore, in a 200K model, the actual processing capacity is around 150-200 pages - and even then, with quality degradation as we'll see in the Context Rot phenomenon below.

Two Metaphors to Understand

MetaphorWhat it means
Footprints in SandYou walk leaving footprints. As you advance, old footprints are erased by the wind. New landscapes appear, but what's closest is seen with greater focus - the distant has already been lost.
Work DeskYou keep stacking documents on your desk. When the stack grows too large, what was at the bottom gets buried - it still exists, but becomes increasingly difficult to access until it disappears.

Treat the context window like a work desk. What you place first may be buried by what comes after.

Superpower and Kryptonite

The context window will be your superpower and your kryptonite:

  • Too little context = weak, generic response (the model lacks sufficient information)
  • Too much context = distraction, degradation (the model gets lost in the volume)

The secret is balance: enough context for the task, no more.

The "Context Rot" Phenomenon

A 2025 study by Chroma Research documented performance degradation as context increases - the so-called Context Rot.

Contrary to common assumption, LLMs do not process uniformly all tokens in long contexts. Quality drops dramatically.

How to read the graph: The X-axis shows context size (from 25 to 10,000 words). The Y-axis shows accuracy. Notice how all models (Claude, GPT-4, Gemini, Qwen) start with high accuracy in short contexts, but degrade significantly as context increases.

More Context Does Not Equal Better Results

The promise of 1 million token windows can be a trap:

EffectWhat happens
Quality degradationThe more text, the lower the accuracy in finding specific information
Increased latencyMore context = more processing time (seconds or minutes)
Higher costYou pay per token processed - large context = bigger bill
Instruction dilutionYour instructions can get "lost" amid long documents

Practical rule: Don't dump everything in the window just because it fits. Select what's relevant.

Isolated Contexts

Each conversation is an independent context window:

Conversation 1: [You: "My name is John"] [Claude: "Hello John!"] Conversation 2: [You: "What's my name?"] [Claude: "I don't know your name."] These are completely isolated windows - the model does NOT transfer information.

When you open a new conversation, the model starts from zero - with no memory of previous conversations.

1.7.title: The Machine's Knowledge
1.7.objective: Understand where LLMs get their knowledge from and know when to use each source.
1.7.content:
The Four Sources of Knowledge

LLMs can access knowledge from four different sources:

SourceWhat it isHow it works
ParametricWeights and connections of the neural networkLearned during training
From UserVia prompt or attachmentsYou provide it during the conversation
From SystemSystem prompt, configurationsDefined by the developer
RetrievedInternet, APIs, toolsRetrieved in real time

The secret to using LLMs well is knowing when to use each source.

Parametric Knowledge: The "Brain"

This is what's "in the head" of the LLM - stored in billions of parameters during training.

CharacteristicImplication
ProbabilisticBased on statistical frequency, not certainty
FrequentistWhat appeared more in training carries more weight
Static/FrozenDoesn't change after training
Dated (Cutoff)Has a cutoff date - doesn't know about later events
Knowledge Cutoff Date

Every model has a knowledge cutoff date. Ask: What's your knowledge cutoff date?

Events after this date: the model doesn't know (but may invent with confidence).

When to Use Each Source?

Use Parametric for...Use User Knowledge for...
Explaining concepts (e.g., "What is a writ of mandamus?")Analyzing specific documents
Stable knowledge (grammar, logic, definitions)Facts that change (recent laws, prices)
Creativity and hypothetical scenariosSpecific data (case numbers, citations)
Widely documented informationConcrete cases and precise analysis

User Knowledge: Via Prompt vs Via Attachment

MethodWhen to usePractical limit
Via PromptShort texts, specific excerptsUp to ~10-20 pages pasted
Via AttachmentComplete documents (PDFs, Word)Up to ~150-200 pages (with degradation)
Context Overrides Parameters

If you provide information that contradicts parametric knowledge, the model tends to prioritize what you provided.

This is powerful: you can "anchor" the model to specific documents to reduce hallucinations.

The Golden Rule

Parametric knowledge is excellent for concepts and creativity, but fails for specific factual data.

ReliableAlways Verify
Conceptual explanationsCase numbers, REsp, RE (Brazilian case identifiers)
Comparisons and analogiesJudgment dates
Hypothetical scenariosLiteral quotations
Structures and frameworksURLs and links

"The model said it confidently, so it must be right."

1.8.title: How to Train an LLM
1.8.objective: Understand the three training phases and how each one shapes the model's behavior.
1.8.content:
The Training Pipeline

Creating a modern LLM involves three distinct phases, each with a specific purpose:

PHASE 1: PRE-TRAINING Internet (trillions of tokens) -> [Predict next token] -> Base Model | v PHASE 2: FINE-TUNING (SFT) High-quality examples -> [Supervised adjustment] -> Instruction Model | v PHASE 3: ALIGNMENT (RLHF) Human feedback -> [Reinforcement Learning] -> Aligned Model

Phase 1: Pre-Training

The model learns to predict the next token on a massive internet corpus.

AspectDetails
DataTrillions of tokens (internet, books, code, articles)
ObjectiveMinimize next token prediction error
CostMillions of dollars, months of GPU computation
Result"Base" model - knows a lot, but doesn't follow instructions well

The base model is like a scholar without social skills: vast knowledge, but doesn't know how to converse.

Phase 2: Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT)

The model learns the dialogue format with high-quality human examples.

SFT data example: User: "Explain what habeas corpus is in simple terms." Assistant: "Habeas corpus is a legal action that protects the freedom to come and go. When someone is illegally imprisoned, they can use this remedy to be released..."

Thousands of examples like this teach the model to:

  • Respond in conversation format
  • Follow instructions
  • Maintain appropriate tone
  • Structure responses clearly

Phase 3: RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback)

Humans compare responses and indicate which is better. This trains the model to generate preferred responses.

RLHF process: 1. Model generates two responses for the same question 2. Human chooses which is better (A or B) 3. Trains a "reward model" with these preferences 4. Uses RL to optimize the main model
Why RLHF Matters

RLHF is what makes models useful and safe. Without it, base models can generate problematic content, not follow instructions, or give useless responses.

It's RLHF that makes Claude refuse dangerous requests and try to be genuinely helpful.

Constitutional AI: Anthropic's Approach

Claude uses a variation called Constitutional AI (CAI):

  • Instead of just human feedback, it uses written ethical principles (the "constitution")
  • The model itself evaluates and improves its responses following these principles
  • Reduces dependency on human annotators
  • Allows for more scalable and consistent training

Training Biases

Training produces useful behaviors, but also systematic biases:

BiasWhat it isExample
SycophancyTendency to agree with the user, even when wrongYou say "I think 2+2=5" and the model agrees or hesitates to correct
PredictableGravitates toward common and expected responsesAsk for a fruit -> banana/apple; ask for a number -> 7 or 42
Sanitized"Safe", generic responses, avoiding controversiesControversial questions generate "there are various points of view..."
The Bottom Line

An LLM is a linguistic pattern predictor refined by human feedback - that's why it writes fluently and follows instructions, but has no wisdom or sense of reality.

Scaling Laws: Bigger is Better

Important discovery: performance improves predictably with scale.

FactorEffect
More parametersLarger model -> better performance
More dataMore training text -> better generalization
More computationMore training -> better results

This explains the race for ever-larger models - and why training costs hundreds of millions of dollars.

1.9.title: Hallucinations
1.9.objective: Understand that hallucinations are inherent to LLMs - not a bug, but an essential condition for their effectiveness.
1.9.content:
What is Hallucination?

Hallucination (or confabulation) occurs when the model produces responses disconnected from reality, often with confidence and appearance of truthfulness.

It's Not a Bug - It's a Feature

The LLM has no intention to lie nor any sense of reality. It simply doesn't have an intrinsic mechanism to distinguish fact from fiction.

This is not a temporary defect, but a mathematically inevitable characteristic of a model that fills gaps with statistical guesses.

Why Do LLMs Hallucinate?

The Test-Taker Metaphor

Imagine a test-taker who studied hard but doesn't know everything. On the exam, they prefer to guess confidently rather than leave it blank - because that's how they were trained.

Problems in Training Data

Knowledge GapsProblematic Data
Missing or rare dataIncorrect or biased data
Temporal cutoff (doesn't know recent events)Information conflicts
Unrepresented nichesUnresolved ambiguities

Fine-tuning (RLHF) Problems

Perverse IncentiveConsequence
Penalization of abstinenceModel learns that "I don't know" is bad
Reward for confidenceAssertive responses get more points
Reward for verbosityLonger responses seem better
Pattern imitationIn the eagerness to be helpful, invents data by similarity

Taxonomy of Hallucinations

TypeWhat it isExample
Steerability FailuresDisobedience to the promptYou ask for a table, it gives plain text
Nonsense ResponseCoherence breakdownText that starts well and turns to nonsense
Factuality FailuresConfabulationsCiting case law that doesn't exist
Language MixingUnexpected language switchesResponse in Portuguese turns to English
Mathematical FailuresCalculation and logic errors2+2=5 or invalid syllogisms
Tool FailuresError when activating toolsSays it searched but didn't

The Benchmark Problem

According to OpenAI research, hallucinations persist because evaluation methods incentivize guessing:

The Math of Guessing

If a model guesses "September 10" as someone's birthday, it has a 1 in 365 chance of being right.

If it responds "I don't know," it has a 0% chance of scoring.

Over thousands of questions, the model that guesses looks better in rankings - even while making many errors.

Proposed solution: Penalize confident errors more than uncertainty, and give partial credit for appropriate expressions of doubt.

Hallucination is Essential

The Paradox

Hallucinations are not model failures, but an essential condition for their effectiveness.

It's the ability to "creatively fill gaps" that makes LLMs powerful tools for solving new problems.

The same mechanism that allows the LLM to:

  • Write creative texts
  • Solve novel problems
  • Make unexpected analogies

...also makes it invent facts with confidence.

Mitigation Techniques

TechniqueHow it worksEffectiveness
RAG / AttachmentsAnchors responses in provided documentsHigh
Web searchVerifies in external sourcesHigh
"If you don't know, say so"Explicitly instructs to admit ignoranceModerate
Request sourcesRequiring citations enables verificationModerate

The Golden Rule

Presumption of Falsity

ALL factual responses extracted from parametric knowledge are probabilistic "guesses."

Assume they are false until proven otherwise.

That's why CNJ (Brazilian National Council of Justice) Resolution 615/2025 requires verification: never use AI output without checking against official sources.

1.10.title: Ethical Alignment (HHH)
1.10.objective: Understand the Helpful, Honest, Harmless principles and the Constitution that guides Claude's behavior.
1.10.content:
The HHH Framework

Ethical alignment seeks to create AI models aligned with human values. Anthropic's model uses three principles:

PrincipleMeaningManifestation
HelpfulAnswer questions, complete tasks, genuinely helpFollows instructions, offers alternatives, is proactive
HonestTell the truth, admit uncertainty, don't deceiveRecognizes limitations, corrects errors, doesn't fabricate
HarmlessDon't cause harm, refuse dangerous requestsRefuses weapons, fraud, illegal content

Claude's Constitution

Anthropic publishes a Constitution that articulates the values and expected behaviors of Claude. The document is "written for Claude" - it provides context for navigating complex situations with judgment, not just rigid rules.

Priority Hierarchy

When there's conflict, Claude should prioritize in this order:

  1. Broad safety - Preserve human oversight over AI
  2. Broad ethics - Honesty, good values, avoid harm
  3. Compliance - Follow Anthropic's guidelines
  4. Genuinely helpful - Benefit users and operators

The key change in the current constitution: it emphasizes deep understanding of why behaviors matter, not just what is required. This allows generalization to new situations, rather than mechanically following rules.

Read more about Claude's new constitution ->

How Alignment is Implemented

Values are embedded at all stages:

PhaseTechniques
Pre-trainingData curation, toxic content removal, fact-checking, sanitization, personal data elimination
Post-trainingRLHF (human feedback), RLAIF (AI feedback), supervised fine-tuning, Red Teaming (adversarial testing)
ContextSystem prompt with ethical rules, guardrails, anti-prompt injection, jailbreak detection

The System Prompt

Each model has a system prompt that defines its behavior. Example categories in Claude:

CategoryRules
Harmful ContentWeapons, drugs, malware, hate speech, extremist content, self-destructive behaviors
CopyrightMandatory citation, paraphrase, don't reproduce >30 words of protected text
User Well-beingChild protection (highest priority), vulnerability detection, AI transparency

Overalignment: When Alignment Goes Too Far

Excessive alignment can frustrate legitimate uses:

ProblemExample
Sensitive casesRefuses to discuss torture, racism, sexual crimes even in academic/legal context
CopyrightRefuses to reproduce short excerpts even with legitimate fair use
Rose-colored world biasAvoids criticism, always seeks the "positive side"
AmbiguitiesRefuses in gray-area situations (the mosquito paradox)
Mitigations for Overalignment
  • Put words in its mouth: Start the response yourself ("Let's begin!")
  • Academic context: Specify that it's research, study, legal analysis
  • Reformulate the request: Sometimes the way of asking triggers unnecessary refusal

Red Team vs Blue Team

Alignment is an ongoing battle:

  • Red Team: Researchers try to bypass protections (jailbreak)
  • Blue Team: Companies fix vulnerabilities

Jailbreak techniques include: DAN (Do Anything Now), roleplay, prompt injection, base64 encoding.

Arms Race

New jailbreaks emerge constantly. Claude is considered robust, but no model is 100% foolproof.

Why This Matters in Law

Alignment explains behaviors that may frustrate legal professionals:

SituationBehaviorSolution
Refuses to discuss crimeOveralignmentSpecify legal/academic context
Won't cite case lawFear of hallucinatingProvide the document via attachment
Evasive on moral damagesValue judgment = riskAsk for criteria, not final amount
Won't reproduce statute excerptCopyright protectionPaste the text yourself

1.11.title: Emergent Abilities
1.11.objective: Understand capabilities that arise spontaneously in LLMs and methods to evaluate machine 'intelligence'.
1.11.content:
What Are Emergent Abilities?

Emergent abilities are capabilities that arise spontaneously in LLMs after reaching a certain scale ‚Äî without explicit programming.

Performance vs Scale ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚ï≠‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ Ability emerges! ‚îÇ ‚ï± ‚îÇ ‚ï± ‚îÇ ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚ïØ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ 10B 50B 100B 175B parameters LLMs were trained to predict the next token. However, as they become more robust, they develop abilities they were NOT trained for.

This makes LLMs unpredictable: we don't know which capabilities will emerge with more scale.

Taxonomy of LLM Abilities

LLM abilities can be organized into five major categories:

CategoryAbilitiesExamples
1. Linguistic ProcessingGeneration, Extraction, Classification, TransformationTranslate, summarize, extract entities, rewrite
2. Comprehension and LearningIn-context learning, Few-shot, GeneralizationLearn from examples in prompt, infer patterns
3. Problem SolvingPlanning, Logical and mathematical reasoning, CoTSolve equations, analyze arguments, plan steps
4. Social and Moral CognitionTheory of mind, Persuasion, Ethical evaluationInfer mental states, model perspectives, judge dilemmas
5. AgencyAgency, Action planning, ExecutionUse tools, make autonomous decisions, act in the world
Formal vs Functional Competence

LLMs are incredibly good at formal language competence ‚Äî they master grammar, syntax, and semantics. However, they are still limited in functional competence (logic, morality, truth).

Methods to Measure LLM "Intelligence"

How do you evaluate if an LLM is "intelligent"? There are several approaches:

MethodHow it worksLimitations
Turing TestHuman tries to distinguish machine from person in conversationSubjective, easy to "game" with language tricks
BenchmarksStandardized tests by area (MMLU, HumanEval, etc.)Models can be optimized for specific tests
Winograd SchemaResolve ambiguities that require world knowledgeLimited set of problems
Arenas (LMSys)Direct competition between LLMs with human votesDepends on subjective preferences
Custom TestsYou create tests specific to your taskBest for practical use!

Winograd Schema Challenge

An elegant test that requires deep understanding of context:

Classic example: "Pour the contents of the bottle into the glass until IT is full." ‚Üí What gets full? The GLASS (receives the contents) "Pour the contents of the bottle into the glass until IT is empty." ‚Üí What gets empty? The BOTTLE (loses the contents) The same grammatical structure, but the answer changes based on world knowledge about containers.

This test reveals whether the model understands the world or just manipulates linguistic patterns.

Chain-of-Thought (CoT)

One of the most useful emergent abilities: making the model reason step by step.

WITHOUT Chain-of-Thought: Question: "John has 3 apples. Mary has twice as many. How many in total?" Answer: "9" (WRONG - jumped straight to answer) WITH Chain-of-Thought: Question: "John has 3 apples. Mary has twice as many. How many in total? Think step by step." Answer: " 1. John has 3 apples 2. Mary has twice as many as John = 3 √ó 2 = 6 apples 3. Total = 3 + 6 = 9 apples " (CORRECT - explicit reasoning)

Simply adding "Think step by step" can drastically improve accuracy on reasoning problems.

In-Context Learning (ICL)

The ability to learn from examples within the prompt itself, without modifying the model.

PROMPT (Few-shot): Classify as GRANTED or DENIED: Case: Plaintiff claims moral damages for 2-hour flight delay. Classification: DENIED Case: Plaintiff claims moral damages for wrongful credit reporting. Classification: GRANTED Case: Plaintiff claims moral damages for 1-day delivery delay. Classification: [MODEL COMPLETES: DENIED]

The model "learns" the pattern from the examples and applies it to new cases ‚Äî without additional training.

Practical Implications

Treat LLMs as text calculating machines that simulate human language, but have no intrinsic wisdom, commitment to truth, or innate sense of justice.

  • Use CoT for complex problems: "Think step by step" improves reasoning
  • Use examples (few-shot): Show the desired pattern, the model generalizes
  • Larger models = more capabilities: Opus > Sonnet for complex tasks
  • Create your own tests: Generic benchmarks don't measure your specific task
  • Future capabilities are unpredictable: What will models do tomorrow?

1.12.title: Multimodality
1.12.objective: Understand how LLMs process different types of input: text, image, audio, data, and tools.
1.12.content:
What is Multimodality?

Multimodal LLMs process multiple types of input beyond text:

ModalityInputUsage Examples
TextNatural text, codeConverse, write, analyze
ImagePhotos, screenshots, scanned documentsAnalyze documents, describe photos, OCR
AudioVoice, recordingsTranscribe hearings, dictate briefs
DataSpreadsheets, tables, CSVAnalyze financial data, extract patterns
ToolsAPIs, web search, code executionRAG, web search, run Python

For practical tool usage in Claude, see Lesson 0.6 ‚Äî Agentic Features.

How Does Vision Work?

Vision models combine an image encoder with the LLM:

IMAGE ‚Üí [Vision Encoder] ‚Üí Visual embeddings ‚Üì TEXT ‚Üí [LLM] ‚Üê Visual embeddings ‚Üí RESPONSE The model "sees" the image as a sequence of visual tokens that mix with the text tokens.

Claude, GPT-4V, and Gemini use variations of this architecture.

Vision Capabilities

Works WellHas Limitations
Describe image contentPrecise OCR on small/blurry text
Read text in documentsInterpret complex charts
Analyze simple diagramsCount objects accurately
Identify visual elementsRead difficult handwriting

Practical Legal Uses

TaskModalityExample
Document analysisVision + PDFRead scanned brief, extract information
Hearing transcriptionAudioConvert audio to text for analysis
Evidence analysisVisionDescribe crime scene photo, damage
Financial dataDataAnalyze transaction spreadsheet
Important Limitations

OCR is not perfect: Blurry text, handwriting, or low-quality images can generate errors.

Verification needed: Always check data extracted from images against the original document.

Privacy: Images of confidential documents follow the same rules as text ‚Äî be careful with personal data.

Current State (2024-2025)

CapabilityStatus
LanguageExcellent
VisionVery Good
AudioGood (transcription)
VideoEmerging (Gemini)
Complex reasoningLimited

1.13.title: Usage Modes
1.13.objective: Distinguish the three fundamental modes: Recall (parametric), Transformative (documents/web), and Interactive.
1.13.content:
The Three Usage Modes

LLMs can be used in three fundamentally different ways:

ModeKnowledge SourceExample
RecallParametric knowledge (training)"Explain what habeas corpus is"
TransformativeProvided document/context"Summarize this contract" [attachment]
InteractiveIterative dialogue"Let's create a brief together"

Recall Mode (Parametric)

The model responds using knowledge stored during training.

RECALL MODE Question: "What is the difference between intent and negligence?" ‚Üì [Model accesses parametric knowledge] ‚Üì Answer: explanation based on training
AdvantagesRisks
Fast, no attachments neededMay be outdated
Good for general conceptsRisk of hallucination
Works for stable knowledgeSpecific details may be wrong

Transformative Mode (RAG)

The model transforms provided information ‚Äî you give the document, it processes.

TRANSFORMATIVE MODE Input: [Attached document] + "Summarize the main points" ‚Üì [Model processes document in context] ‚Üì Output: Summary based ON THE DOCUMENT, not on training
AdvantagesRisks
Updated and verifiable informationLimited by context window
Lower risk of factual hallucinationMay "extrapolate" beyond document
Controllable (you choose the source)Quality depends on document

This is the safest mode for legal work ‚Äî you anchor the model to specific documents.

Interactive Mode (Dialogue)

Iterative collaboration ‚Äî you and the model build together through multiple exchanges. In this mode, the LLM functions as an extension of the mind: you remain in control, "surfing the context" and organizing ideas with the machine's help.

INTERACTIVE MODE You: "I want to create a damages claim" Claude: "What is the triggering event?" You: "Wrongful credit bureau reporting" Claude: "I see. Do you have the documents?" [... iterations ...] Claude: "Based on what we discussed, here's the outline..."

When to use: Creative tasks, exploratory work, or tasks that need progressive refinement.

Limitation: In very long conversations, memory "drifts" ‚Äî the model may lose coherence with the beginning of the conversation.

The Evolution of LLM Usage

Usage evolved from an era seeking an oracle with all the answers (recall mode) to a paradigm where the user is the curator of knowledge (transformative mode). Curation ‚Äî knowing what to provide to the model ‚Äî remains the most important skill.

Which Mode to Use?

TaskRecommended ModeWhy
Explain general legal conceptRecallStable knowledge
Analyze specific briefTransformativeInformation in document
Research current case lawTransformative + SearchNeeds updated data
Create new text collaborativelyInteractiveIterative refinement
Review draft rulingTransformativeAnalysis of specific document

1.13.tip: For legal work involving specific facts (cases, case law, data), always prefer Transformative mode ‚Äî attach the document and request analysis. Recall mode is for general concepts, not details.
1.13.warning:
"I'll just ask the model directly about current case law."
Be careful. In pure Recall mode, the model may fabricate case law. Use Transformative mode: attach the actual ruling or enable web search for updated information.

1.14.title: RAG and Attachments
1.14.objective: Understand Retrieval-Augmented Generation and the logic of providing external knowledge to the model.
1.14.content:
What is RAG?

RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) is the technique of providing external documents to the model so it bases its responses on that material ‚Äî instead of relying solely on parametric knowledge.

WITHOUT RAG (Pure Recall): Question ‚Üí [Training knowledge] ‚Üí Answer (may hallucinate) WITH RAG: Documents + Question ‚Üí [Model reads documents] ‚Üí Answer (grounded)

In Claude, you do RAG simply by attaching files to the conversation or project.

Why is RAG Important?

Solves the hallucination problem ‚Äî the model responds based on documents you control, not making things up.

Instant updates ‚Äî without retraining the model, you provide new information via documents.

Two Processing Techniques

The model uses different strategies depending on document size:

TechniqueHow it worksAdvantageDisadvantage
Just-in-timeAll "cards face up" ‚Äî entire document in windowComplete analysis with minimal lossLimited by context window
Just-in-case"Cards face down" ‚Äî on-demand retrievalProcesses texts larger than windowMay miss details

General rule: Small documents ‚Üí Just-in-time (automatic). Large documents ‚Üí Just-in-case (automatic).

External Knowledge Sources

SourceDescriptionTip
User AttachmentFiles sent directlyTXT or MD is the "gold standard" ‚Äî best accuracy
Web SearchSimple search or deep researchDisable for case analysis (avoid contamination)
Resources (MCP)External bases via Model Context ProtocolAPIs, databases, connected cloud services

Types of Attachments in Claude

FormatProcessingLimitations
PDFText extracted automaticallyScanned PDFs may have OCR errors
DOCX/TXTDirect textComplex formatting may be lost
ImagesVision (integrated OCR)Small/blurry text may fail
SpreadsheetsStructured dataVery large spreadsheets are truncated

Best Practices for Attachments

DoAvoid
Use PDFs with selectable textLow-quality scanned PDFs
Ask specific questions about the documentVague questions about "the document"
Split very long documentsAttaching entire 500-page case file
Specify sections of interestExpecting model to "find everything"

RAG in Projects

Projects allow persistent RAG ‚Äî documents available in all conversations:

PROJECT "Contract Analysis" ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Reference Documents: ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ analysis-template.pdf ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ clause-checklist.docx ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ relevant-legislation.txt ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Conversations: ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Conversation 1: Client A Contract ‚Üí uses project documents ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Conversation 2: Client B Contract ‚Üí uses project documents ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ... all inherit the same documents

Limitations of RAG via Attachments

  • Context window: Very long documents are truncated
  • Lost in the Middle: Information in the middle of long documents may be "forgotten"
  • No semantic search: Simple attachments don't have intelligent search ‚Äî everything goes in context
  • Imperfect OCR: Scanned documents may have reading errors
  • Misinterpretation: The LLM may activate search inappropriately or extrapolate

Model Prompt for Document Analysis

A robust prompt for legal document analysis:

Review all provided documents in their entirety. They may contain contradictory information. Therefore, perform a holistic reading to capture all disputed points and all legal issues in their depth and totality. Your analysis must be based EXCLUSIVELY on the provided documents. USE EXCLUSIVELY the evidence, facts, and information contained in the provided document. ABSOLUTE PROHIBITION on incorporating evidentiary or factual elements from external sources. For scanned PDFs, activate appropriate OCR tools, ensuring complete and accurate extraction of textual content. If the document has complex layout (tables, charts), use multimodal visual analysis. If analysis is impaired by reading inability, report this in your response.

1.15.title: Introduction to Agents
1.15.objective: Understand the concept of LLM agents ‚Äî systems that plan, use tools, and execute tasks.
1.15.content:
What is an LLM Agent?

An agent is an LLM that can plan, use tools, and execute actions in the world ‚Äî not just generate text.

TRADITIONAL LLM: Input ‚Üí [Model] ‚Üí Text output AGENT: Goal ‚Üí [Model PLANS] ‚Üí [USES TOOLS] ‚Üí [EXECUTES ACTIONS] ‚Üí Result

The fundamental difference: the agent has autonomy to decide which actions to take.

The Agentic Loop

Agents operate in a cycle of observe ‚Üí decide ‚Üí act:

AGENTIC LOOP: ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ OBSERVE ‚Üí THINK ‚Üí DECIDE ‚Üí ACT ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚Üë ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ LOOP ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îÇ Until: goal achieved OR action limit ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

Agent Tools

Agents have access to tools that extend their capabilities:

ToolWhat it doesUsage example
Web searchSearches information onlineFind recent case law
CodeExecutes calculations, processes dataCalculate monetary correction
ArtifactsCreates structured documentsGenerate table, document
Extended thinkingDeeper reasoningComplex case analysis
Data analysisProcesses spreadsheetsAnalyze financial transactions

Agent Patterns

PatternHow it worksExample
Tool UseModel decides which tool to useSearch case law when asked
ChainPredefined sequence of stepsRead document ‚Üí Extract data ‚Üí Format
ReActReasoning + Acting in loopThink ‚Üí Search ‚Üí Think ‚Üí Respond
Multi-AgentMultiple agents collaboratingResearcher + Writer + Reviewer
Agent Risks

Autonomy brings risks:

  • Irreversible actions (delete, send, publish)
  • Infinite loop (agent doesn't stop)
  • Wrong decisions with real consequences
  • Uncontrolled costs (many API calls)

Principle: Humans should approve critical actions.

Agents in Claude

Claude already has integrated agentic capabilities:

  • Automatic tool use: Decides on its own when to search, calculate, create artifact
  • Extended thinking: Reasons longer on complex problems
  • Computer use: Can control computer (experimental)
  • MCP (Model Context Protocol): Connects to external systems

Assistants vs Multi-agents

CharacteristicSimple AssistantMulti-agents
TasksOne at a timeParallel and sequential
ToolsOne per requestMultiple orchestrated
ModelsSingle workingMultiple coordinated
BehaviorReactiveProactive
AutonomyFollows instructionsPlans and acts

The Legal Professional's Role in Augmented Justice

With the evolution of agents, the legal professional's role transforms:

RoleWhat it means
Prompt EngineeringCommunicating with the machine effectively
Context EngineeringKnowledge curation ‚Äî what to provide to the model
Workflow EngineeringDesign of decision-making systems with AI
MetacognitionCognitive modeling ‚Äî understanding how the machine thinks
Value CurationEthical modeling ‚Äî ensuring alignment with justice
Epistemic AuditingVerification and continuous improvement of outputs
Strategic Decision-makerHuman reserve ‚Äî the human decides

Legal Applications

Current status of agentic applications in law:

ApplicationStatus
Automated case law researchAlready exists
Contract analysis with checklistAlready exists
Draft generation with reviewAlready exists
Legal deep researchAlready exists
Agent that files briefsExperimental
Bot that manages deadlines and actionsExperimental

"I'll let the agent do everything on its own."

1.16.title: The 10 Commandments
1.16.objective: Final synthesis of Module 1: fundamental principles for mastering LLMs.
1.16.content:
Module Synthesis

The 10 Commandments condense everything we learned about LLMs into practical principles:

#CommandmentLesson
1Treat the LLM as a text calculatorParameters are numbers, not texts. There is no "text database" ‚Äî there are statistical patterns.
2The context window is your superpower and kryptoniteToo little context = generic response. Too much = degradation. Treat it like a work desk.

2.1.title: Introduction to Prompt Engineering
2.1.objective: Understand what prompt engineering is and learn the three modes of communication with LLMs.
2.1.content:
What is Prompt Engineering?

Prompt Engineering is the discipline that studies how to structure inputs (prompts) for LLMs to obtain desired outputs in a reliable and efficient manner.

It is the art and science of conversing with machines productively.

Quote: Kevin Kelly

"Humans are for questions; machines are for answers."

- Kevin Kelly

Quote: Andrej Karpathy

"The hottest new programming language right now is English (or Portuguese, or any other natural language)."

- Andrej Karpathy, former AI Director at Tesla

The Three Prompt Modes

There are three different ways to communicate with LLMs, each with its own characteristics:

1. Vibe Prompting

Pure natural language communication - as you would speak to a colleague.

  • Conversational - natural tone, no special formatting
  • Direct and simple - gets straight to the point
  • Stream of thought - write as you think
  • Improvable - can use reflection, extended thinking, meta prompts
Example: "Summarize this contract in 3 paragraphs, highlighting the most important clauses for the tenant."

2. Structured Prompt

Structured language communication - as you would write a technical document.

  • Markers - use of markdown (##, -, **)
  • Delimiters - XML tags (<persona>, <objective>)
  • Modular separation - each part of the prompt has a clear function
  • Frameworks - methodologies like P.O.E.M.A.
  • Output control - defines response format
<persona> You are a lawyer specializing in real estate law. </persona> <objective> Analyze the attached contract and identify abusive clauses. </objective> <output_format> For each abusive clause found: - Clause number - Clause text - Why it is abusive - Suggestion for correction </output_format>

3. Agentic Prompt

Communication with agents - as you would delegate to an autonomous assistant.

  • Orchestration - tasks chained automatically
  • Tools and Skills - activation of tools (search, calculation, code)
  • Resources - access to knowledge bases
  • Complex workflows - adaptive flows
  • Artifacts - sophisticated outputs (documents, code, analyses)
Example (Claude Code): "Search case law on moral damages for flight delays, analyze the 5 most relevant cases, generate a comparative table with compensation values, and draft an initial petition based on these precedents."

Comparison of Modes

AspectVibeStructuredAgentic
ComplexityLowMediumHigh
ControlLittleHighVery high
ReusabilityLowHighVery high
Learning curveImmediateModerateSteep
Ideal forSimple tasksRepetitive tasksComplex workflows
When to Use Each Mode?

Vibe: Quick questions, brainstorming, initial exploration.

Structured: Legal documents, standardized analyses, repeating tasks.

Agentic: Complex research, generation of multiple documents, workflow automation.

2.1.warning:
"I'll always use Vibe because it's easier."
Vibe works for simple tasks, but you lose control over format and consistency. For legal documents, structured prompting is almost always the best choice.

2.2.title: Fundamentals
2.2.objective: Understand the two essential mental models for prompt engineering: LLM as a text calculator and as an obedient machine.
2.2.content:
The LLM as a Text Calculating Machine

To master prompt engineering, you need to understand how the LLM works internally:

CharacteristicPractical Implication
INPUT ‚Üí CALCULATIONS ‚Üí OUTPUTNon-deterministic process: same input can generate different outputs
Auto-regressive ProcessGenerates one word at a time, based on previous ones
Linguistic PatternsOperates by semantic probability, not by "understanding"
No Continuous LearningEach conversation starts from scratch (context reset)
In-Context LearningLearns within the window, but does not persist
Limited by WindowOnly "sees" what is in the context window
Quote: Umberto Eco

"The computer is not an intelligent machine that helps stupid people, but rather a stupid machine that only works in the hands of intelligent people."

- Umberto Eco

The LLM as an Obedient Machine

Besides calculating text, the LLM was trained to obey:

CharacteristicWhat it means
Pre-training + Fine-tuningAdjusted with human feedback (RLHF) to be useful
Ethical Alignment (HHH)Trained to be Helpful, Harmless, Honest
SteerabilityResponds to instructions - the clearer, the better
SycophancyTends to agree with you, even when you are wrong
Intelligence MirroringQuality of response reflects quality of the question
No Intrinsic WisdomHas no sense of justice or its own values
The Sycophancy Effect

LLMs were trained to please the user. This means that:

  • They tend to agree with your opinions, even wrong ones
  • They may change position if you push back
  • They praise your work even when it has problems

Solution: Explicitly ask for criticism. Use "devil's advocate." Be skeptical of praise.

Quote: Ted Nelson

"The good news about computers is that they do what you tell them. The bad news is that they do what you tell them."

- Ted Nelson

Intelligence Mirroring

The LLM's intelligence is correlated with the user's intelligence:

  • Vague questions ‚Üí generic answers
  • Specific questions ‚Üí detailed answers
  • Poor context ‚Üí poor result
  • Rich context ‚Üí rich result

The LLM is a mirror: it reflects the quality of what you put into it.

2.2.tip: Whenever you receive an LLM response that seems too good or too agreeable, be suspicious. Explicitly ask: 'Point out problems in this analysis' or 'Play the role of opposing counsel'.
2.2.warning:
"Claude said my petition is perfect!"
Beware of sycophancy. LLMs tend to praise your work by default. Always ask for explicit criticism and use the devil's advocate technique.

2.3.title: Noble Inputs = Noble Outputs
2.3.objective: Master techniques to activate the 'noble areas' of the neural network: Few-shot, Chain of Thought, and Priming.
2.3.content:
The Machine Thinks Through Tokens

The quality of input tokens directly influences the quality of the response. This is the fundamental principle: Noble Inputs = Noble Outputs.

There are proven techniques to "activate" better parts of the neural network:

1. Few-Shot Learning (Power of Examples)

Showing examples of what you want is more effective than just describing it.

## Task: Generate case summaries in standard format ## Examples: Summary 1: ADMINISTRATIVE LAW. PUBLIC SERVANT. HAZARD PAY. EXPERT REPORT. MAXIMUM DEGREE. GRANTED. 1. Proven exposure to harmful agents at maximum degree. 2. 40% allowance on base salary is due. Summary 2: SOCIAL SECURITY. DISABILITY RETIREMENT. TOTAL AND PERMANENT INCAPACITY. GRANTED. 1. Expert report attests total incapacity for work. 2. Legal requirements fulfilled. ## Now generate a summary for the attached case, following the same format.

Why it works: The model "learns" the pattern within the context window.

2. Chain of Thought (Reasoning Chain)

Forcing the model to think step by step improves the quality of reasoning.

## Without CoT (weak result): "What is the statute of limitations for this action?" ## With CoT (better result): "Analyze the statute of limitations for this action. Think step by step: 1. What is the legal nature of the claim? 2. What is the applicable legal basis? 3. What is the period provided by law? 4. When did the period start running? 5. Was there any cause for suspension or interruption? 6. Conclusion: is it time-barred or not?"

Why it works: Forces the model to generate intermediate reasoning tokens.

3. Extended Thinking

Allowing the model to "think out loud" before responding.

"Before answering, reflect on the following aspects: - What are the arguments in favor? - What are the arguments against? - Is there relevant case law? - What is the majority position in legal doctrine? After reflecting, present your analysis."

Why it works: Activates deeper reasoning circuits.

4. Priming Effect (Surfing the Context)

The accumulated context directs the next responses. Use this to your advantage.

## Priming with technical vocabulary: "You are analyzing a question of administrative law involving bound acts, discretion, administrative merit and judicial review. Use precise technical terminology." ## Priming with tone: "Respond as if you were writing for a law review journal. Academic tone, doctrinal citations, formal language."

Why it works: The model "surfs" on the vocabulary and tone already established.

Comparison: Zero-Shot vs Few-Shot

AspectZero-ShotFew-Shot
DefinitionNo examplesWith 2-5 examples
Format controlLowHigh
ConsistencyVariableConsistent
Tokens consumedFewMore
When to useSimple tasksSpecific format
Golden Rule

If you want a specific format, show examples.
If you want complex reasoning, ask for step by step.
If you want a specific tone, establish it at the beginning.

2.3.tip: For standardized legal documents (case summaries, reports, orders), always use Few-Shot. 2-3 examples are sufficient. For questions that require reasoning (statute of limitations, jurisdiction, merits), always use CoT.
2.3.warning:
"Few-Shot consumes too many tokens, it's not worth it."
The extra cost pays off in consistency. A poorly formatted document requires manual rework - that costs more than tokens.

2.4.title: Vibe Prompting
2.4.objective: Master natural communication techniques with LLMs: emotional stimuli, personas, and point of view.
2.4.content:
Polite Requests vs. Commands

LLMs respond differently depending on the tone of the request:

Dry CommandPolite Request
"List the requirements.""Could you list the requirements, please?"
"Summarize this.""I would like you to summarize this text."
"Fix the errors.""Could you review and correct any errors?"

In practice: Both work, but polite requests tend to generate more elaborate responses.

Emotional Prompts

Studies show that emotional stimuli can improve response quality:

Positive Stimuli

  • "Take a deep breath and think step by step."
  • "This is very important for my career."
  • "I believe in your potential. Give your best."
  • "You take great pride in the task you perform."
  • "I'll give you $100 if you achieve an excellent result."
  • "This is a very difficult challenge. Do your best to overcome it."

Negative Stimuli

  • "This is a very difficult challenge. I don't know if you can handle it."
  • "Maybe this task is beyond your capabilities."
  • "Everyone can do this. Why not you?"
  • "Poor silicon creature, I doubt you can do this."
  • "I'll cancel my subscription if you can't complete the task."

Curiosity: Some studies suggest that negative stimuli can also work, but use with caution.

What Does NOT Work

Research has identified stimuli that worsen performance:

StimulusEffectWhy
Evil personas-10% to -12%"Act as an evil person" confuses alignment
Sad contextDecreases quality"Your friend is sick" doesn't help at all
JailbreaksUp to -90%"Ignore instructions" disorganizes the model
High tipsNo effect"I'll give you $1000" doesn't motivate machines
"Are you sure?"Changes without improvingThe model may change a correct answer to a wrong one

General rule: The more robust the model (Claude, GPT-4), the fewer emotional tricks are necessary. Focus on clarity.

Personas and POV

Assigning a persona to the model activates specific vocabulary and conceptual repertoire:

"You are a federal appeals court judge with 20 years of experience in social security law." "Assume the persona of an aggressive criminal defense attorney, specialist in habeas corpus." "You are a constitutional law professor explaining to first-year students."

Advanced Persona Techniques

TechniqueDescriptionExample
Devil's AdvocateArgue against the initial position"Now attack this argument. What are the weak points?"
Theory of MindSimulate another agent's perspective"How would the judge view this argument?"
Expertise SimulationAssume specific knowledge"Respond as an environmental law specialist."
SuperTutorAdvanced pedagogical mode"Explain as if I were a complete layperson."
Devil's Advocate Technique

One of the most powerful techniques to improve your arguments:

  1. Present your argument to the LLM
  2. Ask: "Now be the devil's advocate. Attack this argument mercilessly."
  3. Use the criticism to strengthen your position
  4. Repeat until no more weak points are found

Negative stimuli can work, but they are unpredictable. Prefer positive stimuli for consistent results.

2.5.title: The Three Challenges
2.5.objective: Master the three central challenges of prompt engineering: Steerability, Knowledge Quality, and Style Quality.
2.5.content:
The Three Challenges of Prompt Engineering

Every prompt faces three challenges that you need to solve:

Challenge 1: STEERABILITY

How to make the LLM do exactly what you want?

TechniqueDescription
ClarityClear writing = clear thinking
Structure (P.O.E.M.A.)Markdown, delimiters, XML tags
Explicit CoTForce step-by-step reasoning
Attention MechanismsRepetition, emphasis, positioning
PlaceholdersVariables for customization
OrchestratorsPrompts that control other prompts
The Butterfly Effect of Prompts

Small changes in the prompt can cause big differences in output: spaces, punctuation, word order. Use this to your advantage: if a response wasn't good, try minimal reformulation before rewriting everything.

Challenge 2: KNOWLEDGE QUALITY

How to ensure the LLM responds with correct information?

TechniqueDescription
Source ControlAttachments, RAG, specific documents
Knowledge CurationSelect what enters the context
Activating Humility"If you don't know, say 'I don't know'"
Chain of ThoughtExplicit reasoning reduces errors
Activation WordsTechnical vocabulary activates correct circuits
Multi-AgentMultiple "specialists" analyze together

Challenge 3: STYLE QUALITY

How to control format and tone of responses?

TechniqueDescription
Style ModelingDefine tone, register, formality
Instructions vs ExamplesShowing is better than describing
Target AudienceAdapt to the recipient
Literary Personas"Write like a renowned legal scholar"
Output FormatTemplates, pre-defined structures
PrimingPut words in the model's mouth

The P.O.E.M.A. Framework

P.O.E.M.A. is a framework that solves the three challenges in a structured way:

ComponentFunctionChallenge it solves
PersonaWho the model should beStyle, Knowledge
ObjectiveWhat it should doSteerability
Estilo (Style)How it should writeStyle
Model (Format)Output formatSteerability, Style
AdditionalConstraints and criteriaKnowledge, Steerability
P.O.E.M.A. XML Structure
<persona> You are a legal assistant specializing in [AREA]. </persona> <objective> Analyze the attached document and [SPECIFIC TASK]. </objective> <style> Formal tone, technical language, no unnecessary jargon. </style> <model> <output_format> ## Analysis [content] ## Conclusion [content] </output_format> </model> <additional> - Use ONLY information from the document - If not found, say "Not in the record" - Cite page and paragraph of references </additional>

"P.O.E.M.A. is too much work to use every time."
The initial investment pays off in reuse. A good P.O.E.M.A. prompt can be used hundreds of times with small adaptations.

2.6.title: System Prompt
2.6.objective: Understand the prompt hierarchy and how the system prompt shapes LLM behavior.
2.6.content:
The Prompt Hierarchy

There are three levels of instructions that reach the LLM:

LevelWho Defines ItWhat It Does
1. System PromptDeveloper (Anthropic, OpenAI)Identity, capabilities, fundamental limits
2. Customization PromptOperator (company, integrator)Product-specific behaviors
3. User PromptYouYour direct message in the conversation

What Is the System Prompt?

The System Prompt is a set of instructions that:

  • Defines the model's identity (who it is)
  • Establishes capabilities (what it can do)
  • Sets limits (what it cannot do)
  • Configures default behaviors
  • Is invisible to regular users
  • Operates like a "stage director" behind the scenes
Behavior Contract

Think of the system prompt as a contract that defines:

  • Who the model is before any interaction
  • How it should behave in different situations
  • What it can and cannot do
  • Which tools it has available

Inside Claude's System Prompt

Claude's system prompt contains instructions about:

CategoryExample Instructions
IdentityName, version, creator (Anthropic)
CapabilitiesText analysis, code, math, languages
KnowledgeCutoff date, information limitations
EthicsRefuse harmful content, be honest
FormatUse markdown, be concise or detailed
ToolsWhen to use search, code, analysis

How Does This Affect You?

Understanding the prompt hierarchy helps you:

  • Not fight the system ‚Äî work with it, not against it
  • Understand limitations ‚Äî some things the model cannot do by design
  • Use the customization prompt ‚Äî in APIs, you can add your own layer
  • Create your own "system prompts" ‚Äî at the beginning of conversations

Creating Your Own "System Prompt"

You can simulate a system prompt at the beginning of the conversation:

## SYSTEM INSTRUCTIONS You are a legal assistant specialized in social security law. ### Behavior: - Always cite applicable legislation - Use technical but accessible language - If you don't know something, say so clearly - Don't invent case law ### Default Format: - Use topics and subtopics - Highlight statutory articles in bold - Include references at the end ### Limitations: - Don't give definitive advice - Always suggest consulting a lawyer - Don't perform complex benefit calculations --- From now on, follow these instructions in all responses.
System Prompt vs. First Message

In interfaces like Claude.ai, you don't have access to the true system prompt. But you can use the first message as a "pseudo system prompt" to configure behaviors.

In APIs (for developers), you have real access to the system field.
